title: borovichok
author: borovichok
content: The Luna 2.0 is being used by scammers to steal wallet seed phrases from potential cryptocurrency beginners and some smart but foolish people. The phrase "No wallet is useless, you don't throw away your wallet" is well-known in the cryptosphere. I believe LoyceV said something similar in a thread I stumbled upon a few weeks ago. The wallet may be empty now, but what about tomorrow? These con artists will keep an eye on your wallet, and one day you might wake up to find it gone! You weren't hacked; instead, the error you made a few years ago has destroyed you.To gather the information I needed, I opened the site through a secure browser rather than using your wallet browser as it is risky.Scam WebsiteCode:https://vocjavha.com/ When you click "Connect wallet"

comments.author: _act_
comments.body: Was it not that airdrop that Lunc (old Luna) holders were given that was worthless? It is even very possible people that do not hold Lunc at the time can see this type of scam and just fall victim of it. One of the safety means is to never input your seed phrase on any site which. Scammers and hackers like to take advantage of what is presently happening in the community just like the Luna airdrop scam.

comments.author: ScamViruS
comments.body: Scammers always try to scam with trending things. Since Luna's incident happened, everyone has been talking about luna. And scammers want to take advantage of this. If you search, you will find many crypto users who fall prey to such scams easily. Because everyone wants to get free money, and if they hear the news of an airdrop, they jump into it without thinking of anything. Thanks for the warning OP. Hopefully after seeing this post new crypto users will be aware of such scams.

comments.author: khaled0111
comments.body: Quote from: borovichok on June 24, 2022, 07:23:18 AMThe phrase "No wallet is useless, you don't throw away your wallet" is well-known in the cryptosphere. I believe LoyceV said something similar in a thread I stumbled upon a few weeks ago.Satoshi recommended against it too:Quote from: satoshi on October 03, 2010, 08:54:07 PMSigh... why delete a wallet instead of moving it aside and keeping the old copy just in case?  You should never delete a wallet.However, if it's a completely new wallet and you never shared any of its addresses with anyone and never posted it anywhere, then it should be OK to delete it without keeping a backup. The chances of someone mistakenly sending coins to it are near zero.Regarding the scam, no  legit service will ask for your wallet seed or private keys and  it is not needed to connect your wallet. I hope no one will fall for it.

comments.author: coin-investor
comments.body: Quote from: khaled0111 on June 24, 2022, 08:27:31 PMRegarding the scam, no  legit service will ask for your wallet seed or private keys and  it is not needed to connect your wallet. I hope no one will fall for it. Anyone who falls for this scam will be a laughing stock of the community the first rule of the thump is you are your own bank,  and not your key, not your coins, these scammers are taking a chance to see if there are people who don't know this basic rule of the thump of Cryptocurrency, I'm sure no there's no idiot that will fall for this in our community.

comments.author: yhiaali3
comments.body: These scam sites have become rampant since Luna collapsed, I got a lot of these on Twitter but I didn't approach any of them because I know very well that they are scams, beginners get fooled by such scams because they are looking for easy profit, if they bothered a bit by reading and searching, they would know of course that Airdrop Luna is distributed only to Luna holders, a screenshot has been taken before and after the hack and the distribution will be done automatically and there will be no need to subscribe to any site, in addition to that, it is not permissible to put Seed or Private Key on any website for whatever reasons.

comments.author: The Cryptovator
comments.body: This type of attempt isn't new in the crypto world. Any third-party website that asks for the seed phrase of other wallets is a 100% scam and they will steal your seed with funds. Usually, beginner and greedy crypto users would fall into this trap. Because most old crypto users are familiar with that type of scam or they know very well to not share your seed phrase with anyone. No matter how trusted is the site. Anyway, thanks for sharing the information. It will help newbies and Google search as well.

comments.author: NotATether
comments.body: Quote from: borovichok on June 24, 2022, 07:23:18 AMTo gather the information I needed, I opened the site through a secure browser rather than using your wallet browser as it is risky."Wallet browser"?  No wonder why scores of people are getting pwned.Maintaining a browsdr is not for the faint of heart as there are myriads of bugs and especially security vulnerabilities that need to be addressed. If you are even slightly late in applying the patches it could have a detremental effect to your users. In the case of these wallet browsers they are probably using an outdated version of Chrome which would make it even easier for hackers to get in as they only have to exploit the same vulnerabilities as in Chrome.
